base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Consider what this means in Set Theory, since predicate logic maps over isomorphically.
"A=>B" means "A \subset B" Some event "A" maps over to the set theoretical idea "(outcome) x \in A".
Using set theory we will calculate probabilities using the a posteriori noition of probabilities: P(A) = [no. of outcomes in A]/[total no. of outcomes]
NB, A is an "event", being a SET of outcomes. The "total" no. of outcomes is the size of the "universal set", ie the set of all outcomes U.
Thus, U should be considered part of the "prior information",so we should write p(A|U) instead of just p(A). Now, p(A|U) == |A|/|U|.
It may be that |U| is not the set of all outcomes -- we may know (as prior info) that the event necessarily is already in some B, a subset of U.
Thus, "B" takes tthe place of "U" ie p(A|B )=|A|/|B| = p(A|BU) (since BU==B)
So we have a Venn diagram of universal set U containing set B which contains set A.
Thus, p(A|BU) \in [ |A|/|U| , 1 ] is the range of values of p(A|BU), where it is p(A|BU) == |A|/|U| == P(A|U) if B==U, which makes sense coz BU==U p(A|BU) == |A|/|A| == 1 if B==A
NB Later, we'll see another perspective of this. The PRODUCT RULE (given in ch2) will be shown to reduce to this syllogism. That rule is a statement of 3 variables A, B, and C, where C is always our prior info, ie our U here. The prior info is the acceptance of the rule "A => B".
See that discussion in ch2, p211.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: Below he enumerates combinations of A,B,C that (AB|C) might be functions of.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: Indeed, that either order must give the same result is exactly what gives BAYES' THEOREM: it's just the statement that the order of acquiring data shouldn't affect the result.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Let's state explicity what F is: F is the function the tells you plausibility of (AB|C) given the 2 sequentially learned plausibilities (B|C) then (A|BC).
Jaynes also gives an argument for why it is ONLY those two plausibilites that should determined, via F, the plausbility (AB|C).

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: It is associativity of AND that gives us THE PRODUCT RULE.

text.escapedText: A general, functional statement of associativity

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: What follows is a derivation of the FORM of the binary f'n F, given the 2 restrictions: 1) That F is an associative 2) That F(x,y) is monotonic in x & y

text.escapedText: NB This defines a particular H for a given G, though we don't know its form

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Proof: If G1(x,y)G2(y,z) is indep of y, then it must have factors being f'ns of y that cancel, so their forms are thus: G1(x,y)=QA(x)B(y) & G2(y,z)=RH(y)C(z) s.t. QRB(y)H(y) = D =indep of y.
( NB G1,G2 do not connote deriv.s, just 2 different f'ns. NB Q,R,D are defined to be consts. )
Thus, B(y)=D/QRH(y) & so G1(x,y)=DA(x)/RH(y) ---(1)
Now, if G1=G2, then (using args x,y for both): DA(x)/RH(y) = RH(x)C(y) ie DA(x)/H(x) = R^2H(y)C(y) NB LHS is f'n of x alone, and RHS is f'n of y alone, Thus, both sides must equal some constant X,
So A(x)=XH(x)/D ---(2)
(1)&(2) give G(x,y)=G1(x,y)=XH(x)/RH(y)
And defining r=X/R we get the result [[ G(x,y)=rH(x)/H(y) ]]
NB We're hiding F here. The above result is really the following, about F: [[ F2(x,y)/F1(x,y) = rH(x)/H(y) ]]

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
NB in the bit after eq2-10 the following fact will be used:
From eq2-2 (monoticity of F in both x and y), F2(x,Y) the numerator and denominator of G(x,y) are non-negative, hence [[ G(x,y)>=0 ]].

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
NB From eq2-4 to here, the intention has been to find the general form of F, which is a f'n defined to be 1) associative, and 2) a monotonic f'n of both args.
The result at this point is "G(x,y)G(y,z) is indep of y", ie [[ D/Dy{ F2(x,y)/F1(x,y)*F2(y,z)/F1(y,z) } ]]
Getting to this point has been a convincing, but unmotivated (except that the end justify the means) sequence of tricks.
Below, "u_x" means "partial deriv. of u wrt x", etc.
A simpler proof of this result could be to start from 0=[ x_z ]_y ----(1) I'm not sure what "x_z" means -- after all, they're both "independent" variables, and so bear no fixed relationship. Nevertheless, a posteriori, one could always assign some functional relationship between them that reflects observations. Perhaps this is too philosophical, though, as the role of "partial derivatives" I only know to be rigorously defined in to ultimately write derivatives of dependent var.s as f'ns of independent ones.
(1), though suggests that the relationship between x and z is independent of y. This is an even more likely assertion of independence.
Anyway, assuming (1), then 0=[ x_z ]_y =[ x_y *y_z ]_y (introducing y) =[ x_u*u_y * y_v*v_z ]_y where we introduced u=F(x,y) & v=F(y,z) in such a way that u is only in factors containing x or y, and v is only in factors containing y or z. Noting x_u=1/u_x & y_v=1/v_y, this gives 0=[ u_y/u_x * v_z/v_y ]_y
[[ 0=[ F2(x,y)/F1(x,y) * F2(y,z)/F2(y,z) ]_y ]] which is the result that then implies F2(x,y)/F1(x,y) = r H(x)/H(y) as eq2-10 suggests.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Buiding up an alternative deriv'n of eq 2-13, using other noted alternatives above, we continue the alternative deriv'n:
(NB below "v_q" means partial diff'n of v wrt q)
v=F(y,z) (by def'n) v_q=F1(y,z)*y_q+F2(y,z)*z_q ie dv = F1(y,z)*dy + F2(y,z)*dz
Using eq 2-10 to factorize, which is F2(y,z)/F1(y,z)=rH(y)/H(z), we get dv = F1(y,z){ dy+rH(y)/H(z)*dz } dv = F1(y,z)H(y){ dy/H(y)+r*dz/H(z) } ------(1)
Taking the statement of associativity, F(u,z) = F(x,v) (req'ment eq2-6) ------(2) we produce [ (2) ]_y / [ (2) ]_x to get: F2(x,v)/F1(x,v) * F1(y,z) = F2(x,y)/F1(x,y) ie H(x)/H(v) * F1(y,z) = H(x)/H(y) ie ( H(x) cancels ) H(y) * F1(y,z) = H(v) --------(3)
Using (3) in (1), we get
[[ dv/H(v) = dy/H(y) + r*dz/H(z) ]] (eq2-13 )

text.escapedText:
eq2-14's form also implies:
w(F(x,y))=w(u)=w(y)w^r(z) w(F(u,z))=w(u)w^r(z) w(F(x,v))=w(x)w^r(v)

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: This follows from the assoc. req'ment, which now is w(F(u,z))=w(F(v,z)). Then expand each side using the form of eq2-14: w[F(y,z)]=w(y)*w^r(z)

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
To make sense of the integral, consider that v=(y,z) describes a surface in 3D space. The more informative form of eq2-13 is:
1/H(v)*v_t = 1/H(y)*y_t + 1/H(z)*z_t (eq2-13) where v_t=deriv. of v wrt parameter t.
With this parameter, y=y(t) & z=z(t) and v=v(t)=v(y(t),z(t)) are all f'ns of t.
Then integrating the form of eq2-13 above from t0 to t1 amounts to integrating the integrands along a parameterized path, {t|for t in [t0..t1]} in the y-z plane. It becomes
[[ S{ 1/H(v)*v_t} = S{1/H(y)*y_t} +S 1/H(z)*z_t} ]] where S{X}=\int_{t=t0}^t={t1}dt X
eq2-15 is missleading because it defines w(x) by putting 'x' as the upper limit of integration. In fact, it should simply be defined with fixed limits of the integration parameter, both upper and lower.
'x' enters the definition of w(x) because w(x) is then a FUNCTIONAL -- a function of a FUNCTION (y, z, v, etc) that outputs a NUMBER.
The definition of w(x) that Jaynes sought with eq2-15, then, is w(x) = exp( S{1/H(x) x_t } ) which has the limits bound up in the definition of S. AS LONG AS t0 and t1 ARE FIXED FOR THE DEFINITION OF w, IT DOESN'T MATTER WHAT THEY ARE -- eq2-14 still holds.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: This is a very unclear definition. Using parameter t, a clearer definition of w(x) is as a functional w(x) = exp{\int_{t0}^{t1} 1/H(x) x_t dt }.

text.escapedText: This is NOT def'n of u: it's simply a restatement of the def'n of F, using the def'ns of u,x,y on p202.
Confusingly, this IS a redef'n of the symbol v which differs from p202.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
This is the general requirement of F(x,y) when F is 1) monotonic in both x and y, which result from qualitative requirements like "if prior info C2 makes B more plausible tha p.i C1, but leaves A's plausibility unchanged, C2 can't make AB LESS plausible than C1 makes it". 2) and associative, which is really the the "consistency" req'ment, ie that the probability of AB be independent of the order in which A and B are learned.
Thus, eq 2-17 IS A GENERAL REQ'MENT OF A MONOTONIC, ASSOCIATIVE, F'N OF 2 ARGS

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
This eq'n comes from expand w(u) & w(v) in the prev. eq'n, which is done using the form of eq2-14.
This eq'n has many factors cancel, leaving w^r(z) == w^{r^2}(z) ----(1) If r!=1, then only trivial forms of w(z) obey (1), viz. w(r)=1.
Thus, we must choose r=1 to allow a general w(x).

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
The first equality, [[ w(AB|C) = w(A|BC) w(B|C) ]] ---(1) is just a restatement of eq2-16 using the def'ns of u,x,y on p202.
Then, by applying the consistency req'ment -- the the order of learning facts shouldn't matter -- get then second eq'n from (1) [[ w(AB|C) = w(B|AC) w(A|C) ]] ----(2)
Alternatively, (2) follows from (1) by swapping symbols A & B, and realising that this doesn't change the RHS of (1) or (2), by virtue of the commutivity of conjunction: AB=BA.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: It's easier to show via the 2nd form, since if A is certain, AB=B & AC=C, thus w(B|C)=w(B|C)w(A|C) which is eq2-19.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
More obviously: If A is certain, AB=B & AC=C, then by the SECOND form of eq2-19 w(B|C)=w(B|C)w(A|C) => w(A|C)=1 or w(B|C)=0 or infinity.
But we have not restrictred B|C; only A|C, so we should use the inference re: w(A|C), not w(B|C)
[[ w(A|C)=1 iff A is certain ]]

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
An alternative deriv'n of eq2-20 is from the SECOND form of eq2-18: w(AB|C) = w(B|AC)w(A|C) ----(1)
Now, if A is impossible, then so is AB, thus w(AB|C)=w(A|C), & (1) is
w(A|C) = w(B|AC)w(A|C) -----(2)
This has two solutions: a) w(B|AC)=1. But: B could be plausible or otherwise, evenif A is impossible, since we've not constrained B. Thus, we shouldn't use the this solution to (2). b) w(A|C) = 0 or infinity.
[[ w(A|C)=0 iff A is impossible ]]

text.escapedText: NB There is a much better deriv'n to eq2-42 in the note there.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
There is an easier way to get to eq2-42 with m=1 fixed by-the-by.
Below "notA"="-A", "D/Dx" is partial deriv. and d/dx is total deriv. "f_x"=="(D/Dx)f"
Consider that A+(-A)==T, so w(A+-A|X)==1. We want to know an expression for w(A+-A|X) in terms of logical expressions of A. Any syntax tree must have NOT nodes with one child, and AND nodes with 2 children. Since AND & NOT are complete, these are the oly needs we need consider.
Thus, any synatax tree will have nodes at the bottom of the tree that look like this exhaustive list: 1: A 2: -A 3: AA 4: (-A)A 5: A(-A) 6:(-A)(-A)
NB *ignore 3 because AA=A * ignore 4 & 5 because (-A)A=F, a constant * ignore 6 since (-A)(-A)=-(A+A)=-A which is 2.
Thus all subtrees at the bottom of any syntax tree are equivalent to A or -A.
NB It is an assumption that an expression w(A+-A) exists, but not an unreasonable one.
NB "X" will always be considered "prior information", ie on the right of the "|". This means that plausibility terms on which w(A+-A) depend are
w(A|AX) == certain w(-A|-AX) == certain w(A|-AX) == impossible w(-A|AX) == impossible
w(A|X) == ?? w(-A|X) == ??
As the 1st 4 are constants, only the last 2 are viable. Thus, by exhaustion, we can firmly state:
1==w(A+-A|X)==f( w(A|X), w(-A|X) ) ---(1) where we want to find the form of f. Letting x=w(A|X). Using the def'n of S: 1==f(x, S(x)) ----(2)
But by the commutivity of "+", (1) above also gives 1==f( S(x), x )
=> f( S, x )==f(x,S) f_S == f_x (deriv. wrt 1st arg) ---(3)
But from (2) diff'ing both sides wrt x 0==f_x + f_S * S'(x) ==f_x + f_x * S'(x) (by eq 3) ==1 + S'(x)
Integrating both sides wrt x gives S(x) == -x +C for some C. Using the requirement S(0)=1 (or likewise S(1)=0) we see C==1, s.t.
[[ S(x) == 1-x ]] (eq 2-42 w/ m=1)
NB Subbing back in to (1) 1 == f( x, 1-x )
One obvious f (uniqueness?) for this is f=(x,y) == x+y. THIS IS VERY SIGNIFICANT: if we know this is f, we can say x+S(x) == 1, ie
SUM RULE [[ w(A|X) + w(-A|X) == 1 ]] (eq 2-47)

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
THE SUM RULE
NB This is derived in a different manner in the note for eq2-42. There it's derived by seeking a function f s.t. w(A+(-A)|X)==f( w(A|X)+w(-A|X) )

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
THE PRODUCT RULE: simply says that the learning of two facts A,B (in the context of prior knowledge C) must produce a plausibility independant of the order in which they're learned.
And there are two such orders A|C, then B|AC & B|C, then A|BC

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
By the product rule p(QC|X)==p(Q|X)p(C|QX), ie p(C|QX)==p(QC|X)/p(Q|X)
if Q==A+B LHS==p(C|(A+B)X), which is what we seek. RHS==p((A+B)C|X)/p(A+B|X) ==p(AC+CB|X)/p(A+B|X) ==[ p(AC+CB|X) ]/p(A+B|X) ==[ p(AC)+p(BC|X) - p(ABC|X)] / [p(A|X) + p(B|X) - p(AB|X)]

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: GENERALISED SUM RULE NB Its deriv'n is by repeated application of sum rule (eq2-47) and product rule (eq2-46).

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Below, "S" means "\Sigma_i"
p(QC|X) == p(Q|X)p(C|QX), ie p(C|QX) == p(QC|X)/p(Q|X)
Thus, if Q==(S A_i), then p(C|(S A_i)X) == p((S A_i)C|X)/p((S A_i)|X) == p(S (A_i C)|X)/p((S A_i)|X) and since all the "minus" terms that would arise from conjunctions of the Ai are zero ("mutually exclusive"), all those terms drop away giving: == [ S p(A_i C|X) ]/[ S p( A_i|X) ] ---(1) == [ S p(A_i |X)p(C|A_i X) ]/[ S p( A_i|X) ] by product rule, which is eq 2-49.
OR a neater form comes from using the product rule the other way from (1) above == [ S p(C|X)p(A_i |CX) ]/[ S p( A_i|X) ] == p(C|X) [ S p(A_i |CX) ]/[ S p( A_i|X) ]

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: As "C" is on the RHS of the "|" in eq 2-52 suggests that it's some "prior information". When the comparsion is drawn between the product rule and the weak syllogisms of ch1 (ie eq 2-53, 2-56, etc) it makes sense for "A=>B" to be "C", since a rule is generally "prior inforrmation". Rules often exist for the age of the universe, for example.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
That is, given C, ie "A=>B", B will always be true if A is, so given C, AB will be true when A is,
ie p(AB|C)==p(A|C)

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
ie Given C ("A=>B"), then if B is false, so is A ("contrapositive"). The 2nd syllogism of eq2-50 gives the contrapositive meaning of the logic of "A=>B".
So, if B is false, ie -B is true, the A is false, meaning A(-B)==FT==F.
Thus, the probability of A(-B) being true, given C, is nil.
ie p(A(-B)|C)=0

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Referring back to the notes for syllogism eq1-1 which described the Venn diagram picture (recall "B \subset of C (ie U) & A \subset B".
The statement that "p(B|C) is very small" means set B is A very small subset of U (ie C). This means knowing an outcome is in B -- a very small subset of C -- gives lots of information. Since A \subset B, as B gets smalelr, it will eventually equal A. In the process of this limit you can see that more inormation will be gleaned by knowing that B is true (given C), than from knowing A is true given BC.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Prob Theory can be seen as divided in to two parts 1) The less contraversial manner in which probabilities of combinations of events are related to probabilities of those "atomic" events. ie probabilities of syntax trees of predicates in terms of probabilities of the leaves of those trees.
2) The more contraversial question of determinining the probabilities of those "atomic" events in the first place. ie What are the probabilities of the LEAVES of the trees.
Thus far we've dealt with part (1). We're yet to deal with part (2).

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
It is this indifference w.r.t. B that, combined with the requirement that equivalent problems should have equivalent analyses, that means p(A1|X) = p(A2|X)
This prinicple ("of indifference") for assigning probabilities to leaves of boolean syntax trees necessarily means that the "prior information" is encoded inthe probabilities.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
So there is a permutation f(i)=k, s.t. p( A_i | B ) = p( A_{f(i)} | B )
5

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
"n! equivalent problems" means that we can stipulate other permuted systems after III, called IV, V, VI, etc.
These are simply speculated systems, so there is no loss of generality in mooting them.
The restictive step is in stating "B is indefferent to the A_i".
That will restrain all n! systems s.t. the p(A_i|B) are equal.
This is because there are n! perumtations -- call them f^1(i)...f^{n!}(i).
Thus for any A_i, there is a permutaion to any other of the A_i via these n! permutations.

text.escapedText: Where B INDIFFERENT to the A_i :

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Thus far p(x) was a seemingly arbitrary function of x, with no obvious reason for using p(x) instead of x.
Now we have shown Base case) THE PRINCIPLE OF INDIFFERENCE will assign the same values to p(A_i | B ) regardless of the form of p. We can use it to get starting values, as long as B is indifferent to the A_i
Recursive Case) By the product and sum rules, we can find formulas for the probabilities of ALL the logical combinations of the A_i. We know "ALL" because the product rule gives a formula for AND, and the sum rule gives a formula for NOT, and these two logical ops form a COMPLETE SET of logical ops.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
The "background info" doesn't say some balls are more likely to be drawn than others. In fact, it says they are the same size and weight, which suggests they are equally likely.
Whatever the case, we've got no info to think that (lambda i,X: p(A_i | X) ) is a function of X.
NB any probabilities we calculate are then dependent on this viewpoint, ie [[ Calcualted probabilities are reliant on our information, and thus cannot be anything more meaningful than statements about our information of the problem. ]]

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
NOTE: the f'n p(x) had some restrictions, but was still quite arbitrary.
The SUM & PRODUCT rules showed that, for a given def'n of p, the rel'ships between a boolean syntax tree and its leaves are fixed.
But still p was arbitrary.
THE PRINCIPLE OF INDIFFERENCE, though, gives the values of the p's for the leaves, which are also independant of the def'n of p.
Thus the whole calculus is independant of the precise def'n of p!!!
The def'n of p, relating p(x) which we have a complete calculus for, to x is then irrelevant, as long as we work with p(x) and not x.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: Thus we have DERIVED the a the statement which is usually given as the DEFINITION of probability, ie ito FREQUENCIES.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Let a=p(A|X) & b=p(B|X), and a<b
then p(AB|X) = p(A|X)p(B|AX) =a*p(B|AX), ie [[ p(AB|X) <= a ]]----(1) since p(B|A)<=1
(1) is an UPPER bound. If a+b>1 too we get a LOWER bound: p(A+B|X)=a+b - p(AB|X) ---(2)
p(AB|X)=a+b - p(A+B|X) p(AB|X) > 1 - p(A+B|X) ---(3) since a+b>1.
Thus, from (1) & (3): [[ p(AB|X) \in ( 1 - p(A+B|X) , a ] ]] (for a<b & a+b>1)
Similarly we can find bounds on the prob. of disj'n too. First let's re-write (1) as p(AB|X) = ae, where e \in [0,1]. Using this in (2): p(A+B|X)=a+b - ae -----(4) =a*(1-e)+b since e \in [0,1], so is (1-e), thus the first term is in [0,1], and hence [[ p(A+B|X) >= b ]] ---(5)
Moreover, if a+b < 1 , from we can say p(A+B|X) < 1 - ae w/ e \in [0,1] but unknown, ie [[ p(A+B|X) < 1 - a ]] --(6) an UPPER bound
Combining (5) & (6): [[ p(A+B|X) \in [ b, 1-a] ]] ---(7) (for a<b & a+b<1)

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: Consideration of infinite sets must not contradict what one obtains by deriving expressions for an appropriate finite-set problem and then observing the expressions as the set size is extrapolated to infinity.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: Since "false => anything", the LHS can be a contradictory set of predicates whose conjunction is thus "false".

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Well... not quite. The correspondence between sets and logic is usually taken to arise from the isomorphism between statements
"predicate A is true" & "x is in set A".
ie the statement "x \in set A" is true in the set-theoretical setting iff "predicate A" is true in the logical setting.
ie The "predicate A" in the logical setting is taken to be the statement "x \in A" in the set theoretcial setting.

text.escapedText: Rules for finding prob. of Boolean syntax trees i.t.o. its prob.s of its leaves.
Rules for finding prob.s of the LEAVES of Boolean syntax trees.
Prob of dawing r reds in a row from an urn w/ N balls inc M red ones. NB You needn't memorize this: it's a special case of HGD (eq3-18)
# ways of ordering (ie WITH NUMBERS PRESENT) a given fixed odering of red/white balls

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
# ways of ordering -- WITH NUMBERS PRESENT ON BALLS -- a given fixed odering of red & white balls. It's the same for any particular ordering of red and white, and accounts for precisely the number of ways of arranging balls INSIDE the red cohort and INSIDE the white one.
c.f. eq3-16, which ignores numbers and counts the # of arrangements of balls identified simply as red or white.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: NB This discussion is really an alternative derivation of eq3-14.

text.escapedText: eq3-12, except w/ N->N-r, M->M-r to account for r balls
eq3-11, but for WHITE balls use N -> N-M, r -> w

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
To see this is the value, consider balls to be coloured red or white AND numbered from 1..n. The numbers will be ultimately disregarded, as though balls were only ever identified by colour.
Then, according to the numbers, there are n! ways of placing the balls: n for the 1st, n-1 for 2nd, etc.
Now that the n balls are in place, consider ONLY RED BALLS: there are r of them, with r! ways of ordering them.
As for white balls, there are w=n-r of them, with (n-r)! ways of ordering them.
By ignoring the numbers, all the different ways of ordering red balls (once all balls are placed) among themselves become identical, reducing the total orderings by r!.
Likewise, by ignoring numbers, the (n-r)! ways of ordering white balls among themselves become identical.
Thus, the #WAYS OF PLACING N WHITE & RED BALLS WITH NO OTHER IDENTIFYING FEATURES INTO N BOXES IS GIVEN BY eq3-16.

text.escapedText: #ways of placing r red balls and (n-r) white ones in n boxes

NB see notes herein
FIRST There is a symmetrised form of eq3-18, viz eq3-62. Calling R=M=# of red in urn W=N-M=#of white in urn w=n-r=# of white drawn
then the RHS becomes (R r)(W w) -------------------- (N n) The LHS is interesting too. eq3-18 specifies r & n, but we can use exactly 2 of {r,w,n} -- any more over-determines the system.
Sim., we can use any 2 of {N,R=M,W=N-M}. These figures are set before the experiment, so are part of "prior info".
But of {r,w,n},n is prior info, while r,w aren't. Thus, the LHS may be h(r,w|R,W) or h(r|R,W,n). The former form is the one that appears later in the GENERALISED HGD (of k kinds), ie eq3-63.
SECOND The HGD should cover the case of eqs 3-11 & 3-12 for when all balls drawn are red (w=0) and all are white (r=0) resp.
If all balls drawn are red, then w=0 & n=r. Thus, n-r=0, so (N-M n-r)=1 and eq3-18 gives h(r|N,M,n) =(M r)/(N n) =(M r)/(N r) which is eq3-11.
Thus the HGD includes the counting problems from which it was derived where one has a string of one colour.
THIRD: Proof of eq3-18 h(r|N,M,n)=(eq3-16)*(eq3-14) =(n r)*(N-n M-r)/(N M)
n! M!(N-M)! (N-n)! =---------------------------------------------- r!(n-r)! N! (M-r)!(N-n-M+r)!
Using not'n M=R, w=n-r, W=N-M
n! R!W! (N-n)! =---------------------------------------------- r!w! N! (R-r)!(W-w)!
n! R! (N-n)! (W w) =---------------------------------------------- r! N! (R-r)!
R! (W w) =---------------------------------------------- r! (R-r)! (N n)
(R r) (W w) =------------------------- (HGD of 2 kinds) (N n)
r=# red balls drawn from urn n=#balls drawn from urn N=#balls in urn M=#red balls in urn

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
...because the most probable r is r'=(n+1)(M+1)/(N+2), so f=r'/n=(n+1)(M+1)/(N+2)/n
and for larger n, (n+1)/n -> 1, so f -> (M+1)/(N+2) ~ M/N

text.escapedText:
'median'
=roughly, for a PDF p(x), with CDF P(X)=\int_{x=0}^{x=X}dx p(x) the median of p(x) is the value X of x s.t. P(X)=0.5

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
This is another clear instance of probabilities describing state of knowlege rather than physical states.
The probability eq3-32 is readily derivable, but is clearly not what we'd get for if we had knowledge of previous draws.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
In this whole section, up to its end on p311, Jaynes is concerned with stressing the idea that probability describes INFORMATION, and NOT CAUSATION.
In turn, this means it's perfectly reasonable for events occuring LATER in time to effect one's reasoning about the probability of events that have happened EARLIER. As he says, this is what archeology is all about!

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: So we assume here that the robot has no knowledge of other draws.5

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
In the absence of knowledge of most other draws, the prob of Rj given Rk MATCHES that of Rk given Rj.
NB the order of k & j doesn't matter.
Of coruse, there's no breach of causality, since the "probabilities" are only numbers stating the knowledge of a reasoning entity.

text.escapedText:
'Exchangable' distributions
Are ones where the probability for a given outcome is determined only by the freq. distrib'n of that outcome, an not by the ordering. Ie, prob. is invariant to reordering of the seq. of events that comprise that outcome.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
ie regrdless of the order of j and k. Again, the point Jaynes is stressing is not simply thre sult 3-40, which is quite intuitive if Rk comes after Rj, but that it holds even if Rk happens BEFORE Rj.
Of course, this is only counterintuitive if you see probabilites as describing CAUSATIONS rather than just information.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: in other words "... we appeal again to Bayes' Theorem for deriving the reverse of the conditional probability".

text.escapedText:
Not 1/2**(n-k)? V
( NB below (N w)="N choose w"=N!/[ w!*(N-w)! ])
No, of course not:that would be the result if there were continually a 50% chance of white. This assumes #red=#white, ie M=N-M ie M=N/2, and also that draws do not change the probabiltiy, which is the case if the trials are done "with replacement" (a different procedure altogether), or if N is so large that taking one ball out barely changes the odds.
So, we look for our 1/2**(n-k) result when using eq3-46 with cond'ns: M=N/2 and N-> \infty.
Define w=n-k.
Then (N-M)=(N/2) and eq3-46 is [ (N/2)!(N-w)! ] / [ N!(N/2-w)! ]
(N/2-0)(N/2-1)(N/2-2)...(N/2-(w-1)) =------------------------------------------------------- ------(1) (N-0)(N-1)(N-2)(N-3)...(N-(w-1))
Now, this is a product of terms of the form [ N/2-a ] / [ N-a ] ------(2) = [ N/2a-1 ] / [ N/a-1 ] where a is \in {0,1,2,...(w-1)}
Now, N -> \infty, so it dwarfs a. ie N/a -> \infty. In such a limit for the above expression, it approaches \infty / \infty, thus we can use L'Hopital's rule! We differentiate wrt N'=N/a lim_{N/a->\infty}[ N/2-a ] / [ N-a ] = {d/dN' [ N'/2-1 ]} / {d/dN' [ N'-1 ]} = 1/2
This is the general simplification of (2) when N>>a. There are w such terms in the product (1): one for 0, one for 1,... one for (w-1). All w of them simplify to 1/2, giving the result that,
FOR N->\infty, w/ M=N/2, (N-M)!(N-n+k)! --------------------- = (1/2)**w = (1/2)**(n-k) N!(N-M-n+k)

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Meff = number of red balls remaining, given the circumstance "Rlater".
Since the "effective number removed" is 6/5, then Meff=M-6/5=2-6/5=10/5-6/5=4/55

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
GIVEN the fact Rlater -- that at least one ball has been removed -- the prob. of balls removed is 1/5.
The GIVEN removed ball must be accounted for, so the effective removed number is 1+1/5=6/5.

text.escapedText: where R=M=#red in urn W=N-M=#white in urn r=#red drawn from urn w=n-r
GENERALISED HYPERGEOMETRIC DISTRIBUTION (of k kinds) Prob. of r_X draws of colour X, w/ N_X of colour X in urn (k=#colours)
SYMMETERISED FORM OF HYPERGEOM. DIST. (of 2 kinds) (equiv to eq3-18)

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
1st, define new symbols N(i)=\Sigma_{j=i+1}^{k}N_j & r(i)=\Sigma_{j=i+1}^{k} r_j
NB r1,r2,ri, etc mean the usual subscripted symbols.
Note that N(0)=N, and r(0)=r
Note, then, that N(i)-N(i-1)=[ \Sigma_{j=i+1}^{k}N_j ] - [ \Sigma_{j=i}^{k}N_j ] = - N_i ie N(i)+N_i = N(i-1).
This means ------------------------------(1) N(1)+N_1 = N(0) N(2)+N_2 = N(1) N(3)+N_3 = N(2) N(4)+N_4 = N(3) etc.
Similarly for r(1).
Now, we approach the problem of a MULTINOMIAL distribution, by starting by considering most of the colours to be identical. We start with only two "colours", namely, the one labelled "1", and "everything else". There are N1 of the first "colour" in the urn, and N(1) of everthing else. The number of ways of drawing balls is then h(r1,r(i)|N1,N(i)).
Now consider 3 colours, N1, N2 & N(2). There are h( r1,r2,r(2) | N1,N2,N(2)) ways of drawing them, but they can be factored in to the number of ways of drawing the 2 colours N1&N(1), and then considering a reduced number of balls which ignores the N1 altogther -- that is, considering how the balls apart from the N1 are drawn.
Thus, we get h( r1,r2,r(2) | N1,N2,N(2))=h( r1,r(1) | N1,N(1))*h( r2,r(2) | N2,N(2))
Applying eq3-62 3 times we get h( r1,r2,r(2) | N1,N2,N(2)) (N1 r1)(N(1) r(1)) (N2 r2) (N(2) r(2)) =------------------------------ x ----------------------------------- (N1+N(1) r1+r(1)) (N2+N(2) r2+r(2))
Using (1) (N1 r1)(N(1) r(1)) (N2 r2) (N(2) r(2)) =------------------------------ x ----------------------------------- (N(0) r(0)) (N(1) r(1))
(N1 r1) (N2 r2) (N(2) r(2)) ----------------------(2) =---------------------------------------- (via cancellation of ( N(1) r(1)) ) (N(0) r(0))
Likewise, for h( r1,r2,r3,r(3) | N1,N2,N3,N(3)) h( r1,r2,r3,r(3) | N1,N2,N3,N(3))=h( r1,r2,r(2) | N1,N2,N(2))*h( r3,r(3) | N3,N(3)) (N1 r1) (N2 r2) (N(2) r(2)) (N3 r3) (N(3) r(3)) =---------------------------------------- x -------------------------------------- (N(0) r(0)) ( N3+N(3) r3+r(3) )
by (2) above (for 1st factor) and eq3-62 (for 2nd) (N1 r1) (N2 r2) (N(2) r(2)) (N3 r3) (N(3) r(3)) =---------------------------------------- x -------------------------------------- (by N(3)+N3=N(2), etc ) (N(0) r(0)) ( N(2) r(2) )
(N1 r1) (N2 r2) (N3 r3) (N(3) r(3)) -----------------------(3) =------------------------------------------------------ (N(0) r(0))
From (2) & (3) we can see the general pattern emerging: h( r1,r2,r3,....,rk,r(k) | N1,N2,N3,...,Nk,N(k))= (N1 r1) (N2 r2) .... (Nk rk) (N(k) r(k)) =------------------------------------------------------ (N(0) r(0))
But note, by def'n of N(i), N(k)=0, & sim. r(k)=0. Also, N(0)=N & r(0)=r. Thus, we get eq3-63 h( r1,r2,r3,....,rk | N1,N2,N3,...,Nk)= (N1 r1) (N2 r2) .... (Nk rk) =---------------------------------------- (N r)

text.escapedText: This sec'n is concerned w/ deriving identities of "N choose r" from HYPERGEOM. DIST.

k=# of "kinds" N_i=# of ith kind in urn
r_i=# of ith kind drawn
Deriv'n here is the specialis'n of HYPERGEOMETRIC distrib'n -> BINOMIAL as M/N=f=const, & N,M -> \infty (More general than my note@eq3-45

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: See this previous note in exercise 3.2.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents:
Consider 1st 2 colours. We're seeking p(r>=1,w>=1|R,W), ie p(r>=1,(n-r)>=1|R,W,n).
So, for a given n, we have some constrains on r, viz. r>=1 and n-r>=1. The different values that r can take describe mut-ex outcomes -- there's exactly 1 red ball, 2 red balls,etc.
Thus, p(r>=1,(n-r)>=1|R,W,n) ==[ \Sigma_{r=0}^{r=n} p(r,n-r | R,W,n) ] - p(r=0,n-r|R,W,n) - p(r=n,n-r|R,W,n) ----(1)
Now, the summation term can be found in several ways. Firstly, not that by expanding the HGD p(...) it becomes [ \Sigma_{r=0}^{r=n} (R r)*(W n-r) ] / (R+W n)
By eq3-67, this summation is itself (R+W n), so (1) becomes p(r>=1,(n-r)>=1|R,W,n) == 1 - p(r=0,n-r|R,W,n) - p(r=n,n-r|R,W,n) ----(2)
ALTERNATIVELY, you could see that the summation was 1 because it covered all cases of a mut-ex set of outcomes.
So, using the def'ns for the HGD pdfs: p(r>=1,(n-r)>=1|R,W,n) == 1 - [ (R 0)(W n-r)+(R r)(W 0)]/(R+W n)
ie p(r>=1,(n-r)>=1|R,W,n) == 1 - [ (W n-r)+(R r)]/(R+W n)
GENERALISING TO >2 COLOURS: Return to the idea that the figure sought is 1-p(r1=0 OR r2=0 OR ... OR rk=0).
Recall: r1 is the number drawn of colour 1, etc. N1 is the number in the urn of colour 1, etc. N=\Sigma N_i r=\Sigma r_i
Consider general form of p(disjunction): p(x1+x2)=p(x1)+p(x2)-p(x1.x2) p(x1+x2+x3)=p(x1+x3)+p(x2)-p((x1+x3).x2) =p(x1+x3)+p(x2) - p(x1.x2+x3.x2) =p(x1+x3)+p(x2) - [ p(x1.x2)+p(x3.x2) - p(x1.x2.x3) ] =p(x1)+p(x2)+p(x3) - [ p(x1.x2)+p(x3.x2)+p(x1.x3) ] + p(x1.x2.x3)
In general p(x1+...+xk)=\Sigma{j=1}^{k} (-1)**(j-1) \Sigma_{x=2^S,|x|=j} p(AND(x)) ------(3) where S={x1,...,xk} In words, it's the sum of probabilities taken 1 at a time, minus the sum of probabilities conjuncted 2 at a time, plus the sum of probabilities conjuncted 3 at a time, minus the sum of probabilities conjuncted 4 at a time, etc.
Now, we must consider these probabilities p(AND(T) ), were T is a subset of the predicates S={"r1=0",...,"rk=0"}.
For some subset T={r1,r2,r3} (say) then the probabilty of not drawing balls "1","2" or "3" is the probability of drawing n balls from N-(N1+N2+N3). Let M=N1+N2+N3, or the some of whatever balls cannot be chosen. This is like choosing from two colours, where one colour is the M balls we can't choose, and the other is the N-M we can. We know already that for two such colours, the probability of choose n-r of the first kind and r of the second is (N-M n-r)(M r)/(N n). Since the M balls "can't be chosen", r=0 and we get (N-M n)(M 0)/(N n) == (N-M n)/(N n) ------(4)
The RHS is the probability of picking n balls from N, where M of that are, as a given, not to be chosen.
If, as in exercise 3.2, the Ni=10 are constant, then we are choosing from N-(j*10) balls. Moreover, when Ni is constant, the inner sum in (3) simplifies to a constant product "(k j)*", since there are (k j) conjuctions of j of k colours. Also, above M becomes M=j*10
Thus, from (3) we get p("r1=0"+...+"rk=0")=\Sigma{j=1}^{k} (-1)**(j-1) (k j) * (N-j*10 n)/(N n) ------(3)
In python this is p=sum([ ((-1)**(j-1)) * float(C(N-Ni*j,n))/float(C(N,n)) * C(k,j) for j in range(1,k+1)]) where C(n,k)=="n choose k"
Thus, the probability of having ONE OF EVERY COLOUR, is the 1-p("r1=0"+...+"rk=0").
Implementing this a priori calculation in python, and also using pseudo-random numbers to run simulations shows good agreement. For k=5, all N_i=10, and n=15, the a priori result is 0.911332, compared to these values determined from ensembles of size 10000: 0.911100, 0.910200, 0.905100, 0.909300, 0.912000, 0.914100, 0.910000
It's hard to solve for n, but using the python a priori solution, n=15 gives the prob above, while n=14 gives the prob (all 5 colours present when n chosen ) of 0.877826.
Thus n=15 is the smallest you need to choose to say with >=90% certainty that every colour is represented.

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: It is in this sense that "drawing with replacement is enormously more complicated". The "assumptions usually made" are ones like "assume the replced ball is mixed in [so that the probability of drawing a red ball from red+white ones doesn't change]."

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: ie, if we find e-(vals,vects) we can get the diagonalisation and then get M^r for arbitrary r.

text.escapedText: Recall, from eq3-87: "p"=prob of red given only C.
Prob that kth draw is red, given for Markovian trials (ie kth trial dep on &(k-1)th) of eq3-80

base.author: Marc Ahrens
base.contents: Unless we have a system for replacing ball somewhere nearer to the bottom, eg. shooting them in to the bottomof the urn.
